page.lettertext:
fol.156r
Maye it please your good L. having nothing to negotiat till I heare from
your L: which I have not done as yet since I came out of
Englande,
I am humbly to beseeche you, yf you thinke it soe meete to lette me
knowe as soone as maye be to w
at
effecte I shall addresse my further
dealing w
th
the
States
. They have taken suche order for supplie
of
e garrisons, as it is not to be doubted, but
t
the enemies forces
beyng presently dispersed, they are very well provyded; and yet theyr
meaning is further as occasion shall requyre, to see them furnished
as fully as they have been at any tyme. I have allsoe ear-
nestly sollicited to knowe an aunswer about
e shipping, which
e
Provinces will sende to
e enterpryse of
Brittanie:
wherein I doe
perceyve by pryvate co
m
unication w
th
some of theyr Deputies,
at
they have full co
m
ission sent unto them to take w
at
order they
thincke meete. But for as muche as my selfe am utterly ignor
a
t
both of
e number of shippes
at
e
her
Ma
tie
will arme, and
of
e tyme
t
is assigned of theyr putting to sea, and of other
besydes very necessarye pointes to be knowne to them heere, before
they can resolve I am forced to forbeare from dealing further w
th
them, till her Highnes further pleasure be notified unto me.
From
e Campe before
Groeninghen
we are thus advertysed. That
e 13th day of this monneth,
e Bourghers made offer to capitulat
w
th
Co: Maurice
, requesting hym to send his Deputies unto them:
which he promised to doe, soe
t
they would send hym hostages, till
the Deputies returned, whereunto where they had yeelded
e Co:
sent his trompette to conduct
e hostages unto hym. But whyle
e trompette was within,
e soldiers of
Verdugo
w
ch
laye entren-
ched in
e suburbes, and were as is thought 700 in number, by
e practise of Jesuits, and w
th
the assistance of certaine mari-
ners, and suche others of
e towne, as dislyked to Capitulate, had
a gate sette open to them, by which they entred unwares to
e
Contrarie fashon, put many to
e Sword
at were in consultati
o
advaunced theyr ensignes about
e walles of
e Towne, and co
m
it-
ted besydes dyvers insolent actes. This was done
e 15 of this pre-
sent, but was unknowne to our armie, till a Bourgher
t
escaped
and lepte over
e walles, came to tell yt Co: Maurice, wheruppon
e nexte daye after he sent them a Dru
m
e, to requyre his trom-
pette and to knowe their resolution. In the tyme of theyr parley, it
was accorded on both sydes,
t
e great Artillerie should not playe,
which was a singular furtherance to
e finishing of our workes,
fol.156v
To my
L. T
r
e
r
June 24 1594
having pearced by
t
meanes into 4 severall places of theyr d
yke
which nowe they labo
r
to fill up. The 17 daye at night
e tr
om-
pette beyng returned Co: Maurice was certefyed
t
e Bour
ghers
had prevayled againste
e souldiers of Verdugo, and
had
driven them agayne into theyr trenches in
e suburbes, wh
ich
is called there
e
Schuytendiep
: And p
nt
ly upon it they re
nued
theyr further sute, by a letter to
e Co: requesting hym ag
aine
to capitulate w
th
them: whereunto he condescended, but
re-
fusing to be bownde as he had been before, not to use h
is
great Artillerie: which he perceaved by some priso
n
ers
did
more terrifie
e Bourghers, w
th
theyr firie Bullets, then a
ny
other force or practise of
e armie. They requyred in ly
ke
manner
at although they should conferre, and agree u
pon new
conditions, they might yet be permitted to take 14 dayes r
espite
to see what succo
r
would come to them, w
ch
they seemed
to de-
maunde, because Co: Maurice once before had seemed
to
make them suche an offer. Howbeyt by his l
re
of
e
19
he replyed unto them,
t
thinges were nowe in another es
tate
and sith
at before they rejected his offer, he would not
grant
soe muche agayne, but in
e worde of Prince he would
assure
them
at there was no succo
r
towardes, using speeches
of
persuasion to drawe them to compownde w
th
out further
delay.
Howe this l
re
is accepted we doe not understand: bu
t every
man supposeth, and theyr manner of proceeding doth ins
inuate
no lesse, but
at they purpose to surrender.
Having had
e sight of an Abstract of
e
Emperors
proposi
tion
in
e Diet of
Ratisbone,
I thought
at yf your L. ha
d not
seene it before, I should not doe amisse to imparte yt u
nto you
for which I send it heere inclosed.
And soe I take
my
humble leave. From
e Hage. June 24 15
94
Your L. most humbly Tho. Bodley
